Draft 4-28-06. Have to agree with Pailhead here, I have some bourbon nose hairs for sure, (cuz for the most part I cant stand the stuff), and didnt detect any in this whatsoever. Neither did I get any oak/wood or vanilla. Pretty convinced it had to be a different beer than what everyone else had. Anyway, Dark transparent amber/mahogany with minimal head. Aroma sort-of hot, but just straight alcohol aroma not bourbon. Plenty of caramel and toffee, no hop presence. Flavor again, all caramel and toffee, very chewy/bready, faint hop character in the finish. Big residuel sweetness aftertaste, borderline cloying. Still a nice BW altogether.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2006 This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation dark ruby red brown colored body and a very good lacing. The mild aroma was malty vinous and sweet. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a strong vinous aftertaste. The strong vinous flavor contained notes of sweet malt and bourbon but was missing the hops. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.  Not sure I would have called this one a barley wine at all.

Dk brown cloudy pour thick brown head hints of red.  Aroma of bourbon & oak some light hints of hop very mellow.  Palate is rich & creamy.  Flavor is buttery bourbon w/ a dry and very sweet grassy finish.  Good but lacks the barleywine characteristics.

On tap at the brewpub on 4/28/06: Pours a clear deep copper mahogany brown with a thin-lacing off-white head.  Rich, sweet caramel bourbony aroma has some vanilla oaky complexity.  Body starts with good sweet caramel malty flavor with lots of oaky vanilla, a touch of butterscotch and some warming alcohol.  A nice, barrel-aged barleywine.
Thanks to Floosmoor for breaking this out for the Ratebeer guys.Wonderful aroma of oak,vanilla along with some very ripe pears.Very nice. Not over done in my opinion.

On tap, FlossmoorRB gathering. Good stuff.  Aroma was light, vanilla and boubon.  Pour was a ruby garnet color.  Flavor was sweet, caramel like. Sugars and fruit combined nicely.  Palate was nicely bodied and finish was sticky but dry. I really enjoyed it.

Draft at Flossmoor Station served in a snifter. Small tan head that mostly diminsihed with nice lacing, transparent, and a ruby hue. Nose was lightly hoppy, vanilla notes, oak, and bourbon. Flavor started off sweet then turned vinuous, and somewhat dry at the end. Tingly, sticky and warm mouthfeel. Medium-full body.

Draft @ Flossmoor Station:  Clear ruby color with a medium sized beige head.  Very sweet malty and fruity aroma.  Notes of cherries is the dominant fruit.  Fair amount of bourbon in the aroma but balanced very nicely.  Light alcohol in the nose.  The flavor was sweet and sugary with a nice amount of fruit and malt.  The bourbon flowed at the finish.  Some alcohol and a nice warming sensation.  Very nice beer.

Since I was driving home, couldnt have more than a sample of this brew.  Too bad.  The best thing Ive had at Flossmoor.  But the sample testified to the quality of this barley wine.  Dark black with red highlights topped by a small, creamy beige head.  Served nicely in a snifter as it should.  Lots of bourbon in the nose along with some milk chocolate, vanilla, sweet cherries, oak cask.  Full bodied with a thick texture.  Warm alcohol feel going down, notes of bourbon, some sweetness, dry finish.  Damn good.

Sweet nectar aroma with a definite bourbon character. Dark red in color, almost opaque, but when held to the light can see the dark reddish color. Excellent lace and yellow head. Strong alcohol profile. Creamy, thick bourbon notes with some hop. Well balanced.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2012 Draft... Pre-DLD06...This beer rocks!... Clear, mahogany ale with a small, creamy, beige head. Great retention. Caramel, light chocolate and light bourbon in the nose. The flavor is sweet, then bitter with notes of caramel and sourmash. Full-bodied and syrupy with medium carbonation. Finishes alcoholic and dry. Very warm, but not nearly as "hot" as Ellas Reserve. World class effort!

Snifter on tap at the Friday Night pre-release DL party, thanks brewers!  The beer displays a deep slighty muddled ruby hue with some oily and sticky cling to the grassware. The aroma has notes of vanilla, oak and bourbon which is very characteristic of Woodford Reserve aging. Also detected some brown sugar, grassy hops, pepper, and earthy esters.  The taste is very sweet at first as well has fruity and a little vinous fig notes but a sharp peppery and alcohol character cuts through and makes it enjoyable. A woody and very dry finish. The mouth feel is very sticky, lush, and full-bodied. Moderately warming as well.  A wonderful take on barrel aging once it opened up let the hops show. Digging it, rating #2400, Another One Bites The Dust, SUTA!

UPDATED: APR 29, 2007 On tap at the brewpub: Deep brown with a tan creamy head. A hint of boubon but not a whole lot. Some vanilla, malts, a little sweetness. Flavor is rich and malty, some subdued hops.

Re-Rate 4/27/2007: This stuff got even better. Mellowed out a lot. Alcohol really softened, everything came together quite well.

On tap at Flossmoor Station, sampled the day of the DL gathering. Pours a dark brown mahogany hue. Nose is not only bourbon, but clearly Woodford Reserve bourbon (yes, its scary that one can pick this out.) On the nose, lots of vanilla, cherry, bourbon, sherry. More of the same on the palate, with a pleasant bourbon/hops/alcohol finish. One of the better barleywines Ive had in awhile, and one that I could see ageing very well. More on the sweeter side, much to my liking.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2007 Draft at FSRB, 4/28/06. Deep dark brown color with a trim half-inch tan head. Deep bourbon smell. Chewy, malty and, um, malty. And then the taste piles on the bourbon and oak. Only halfway down the glass I got a funny feeling in the back of my neck; the hops bitterness finally arrived. Turned out to be my second of three barrel aged beers this weekend.Draft at FS, 6/20/07. Darn thing pulls some surprises a year later. In a snifter, it shows a bubbly head, building up a "curb" around the edge. Heady smell of brandy, raisins and plums. Oddly, the taste is much sweeter than I remembered. On top of the plum notes, theres a bit of Juicy Fruit, like a slight souring. Bigger alcohol warming, with a whiskey finish. I see my origiinal rating of "4.0" is the mean for this brew.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2006 On tap:  Aroma of caramel, toffee, banana bread, and some citrus hops.  Not detecting any bourbon in the nose.  Transparent red with some orange hilights and small of-white head with decent retention.  Lots of sweet caramel and banana bread up front and finishes with mild citrus hops.  Very sticky mouthfeel.  Once again, Im not detecting any bourbon in the flavor.  Had to check with the bartender to make sure they werent serving two different barley wines.  I was assured they werent, but everyone at the Flossmoor gathering noticed a bourbon presence in this beer.  I definitely did not.

Poured a reddish mahogany color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla oak, bourbon, citrus fruits, and sticky caramel malts.  Taste of smoke, dried fruits, caramel malts, citrus fruits, medium bitterness, and medium alcohol in the finish.

Pours to a garnet colored body with a lasting tan head.  The flavor is sweet Maris Otter malts.  Subtle hops.  Subtle barrel aging.  Sweet stickyness.  The palate is sweet, barrely.  The aroma is lightly hoppy, nice sweet malts and barrel aging.  The Woodford Reserve bourbon is barely noticeable but is apparent as beeing that brand.
